did.abstract: United States Representative and Secretary of the Navy; collection includes correspondence, 1880-1927, concerning personal matters, business affairs, and political activities; letters to Mrs. Denby regarding Denbyâ€™s death; articles, speeches, notes and memoranda on various topics including the Teapot Dome Scandal, Panama Canal, relations with China, and the United States Navy; photostats of letters exchanged between Nathaniel Denby and George Bancroft, 1845-1846; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Received from Mrs. Marion Thurber Denby (Donor no. 1458) in 1941.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Edwin Denby papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Edwin Denby was born on February 18, 1870 in Evansville, Indiana to Charles and Martha (Fitch) Denby. In 1885 he moved to China with his father, who had been appointed minister for the United States. Denby lived there for ten years, where he was employed in the Chinese imperial maritime customs service from1887 to 1894. Upon return to America, Denby enrolled in the Law School at the University of Michigan, receiving his L.L.B. in 1896.

Denby volunteered for service in the United States Navy during the Spanish-American War, serving as a gunner's mate aboard the Yosemite. He then returned to Detroit to practice law. Denby was elected as a Republican Representative to the Michigan legislature in 1903, and in 1905 was elected to represent Michigan's 1st District in the United States House of Representatives, serving from 1905 to 1911. After he lost the election in 1910 to Democrat Frank E. Doremus, Denby returned to his law practice in Detroit. When the United States entered World War I in 1917, he enlisted as a private in the United States Marine Corps. Denby retired in 1919 with the rank of Major (United States). He was then selected by President Warren G. Harding to be Secretary of the Navy, in which capacity he served from 1921 to 1924.

Denby is perhaps best known for his involvement in the Teapot Dome oil reserve scandal, which led to his resignation as Secretary of the Navy. In 1921, by executive order of the President, control of naval oil reserves at Teapot Dome, Wyo., and at Elk Hills, Calif., was transferred from the Navy Dept. to the Dept. of the Interior. In 1922, Albert B. Fall, U.S. Secretary of the Interior, leased, without competitive bidding, the Teapot Dome fields to Harry F. Sinclair, an oil operator, and the field at Elk Hills, Calif., to Edward L. Doheny. These transactions became (1922--23) the subject of a Senate investigation conducted by Sen. Thomas J. Walsh. Through the course of the investigation, it was found that Donehy had loaned or given large amounts of money to Fall, presumably in payment for the lucrative oil reserve leases. Fall was eventually indicted for conspiracy and for accepting bribes, and convicted of the latter charge (he was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $100,000).

Denby was not seriously charged, and was determined to have taken no significant part in the negotiations. A quote from The New York Tribune illustrates the public perception of Denby's involvement in the affair: "Stupidity is the high crime and misdemeanor which the Senate accuses Mr. Denby, and the only one." (Feb. 12, 1924). A senate vote on February 11, 1924 requested President Coolidge (Harding had died by this time) to dismiss Denby from his cabinet. Coolidge declined to dismiss Denby, who still insisted that the leases of the oil reserves were both legal and expedient. Nevertheless, Denby resigned his post on February 18, 1924, and in March returned once again to Detroit to practice law. He died there a few weeks before his 59th birthday.

Detroit's Denby High School is named in his honor, as is the Denby Center for Children and Family Services, which the Salvation Army opened in Detroit in 1930 to provide housing and treatment for abused and neglected children.

scopecontent.p: The Edwin Denby papers, dating from 1845-1846 and 1880-1929, are organized into five series: Correspondence, Articles and Speeches, Topical Files, Personal/Biographical, and Photographs. Denby's papers document his political career as United States Representative and Secretary of the Navy, and include relevant information on such topics as the United States Navy, the Panama Canal and the Teapot Dome Scandal.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is organized chronologically, and contains not only correspondence by Edwin Denby but also photostats by Nathanial Denby written to the Secretary of the Navy in 1845-1847 and a copy of Graham N. Fitch and S.A. Douglas' correspondence.

did.unittitle: Photostats of letters written by Nathaniel Denby, U.S. Navy Agent to George Bancroft, Sec. of Navy 1845-1846
Photostats of letters written by Nathaniel Denby U.S. Navy Agent, to John G. Mason, Sec. of Navy 1847-1848
Copy of Graham N. Fitch and S.A. Douglas correspondence January 21, 1859-January 24, 1859

scopecontent.p: The Articles and Speeches series contains articles and speeches written by Denby. The speeches included are organized chronologically where possible, and by topic in the case of undated speeches. Speeches given by Denby in his capacity as a United States Representative, as well as Secretary of the Navy, are included here.

did.unittitle: Detroit White Lead Works speech October 1904
Detroit Board of Commerce speeches October 1912, February 1914, undated
"Men! It is Up to You!" An Address to Applicants for Enlistment in the United States Marine Corps September 1923
Homecoming speech after resignation as Secretary of the Navy, Detroit MI March 13, 1924
Campaign speech for 1904 House of Representatives election
House of Representatives speech on President Roosevelt and the House Appropriations Committee
Letter to the Editor Detroit Free Press
Beaufort, South Carolina article written for The State, May, 1926

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files include material collected and written by Denby on a variety of subjects: including relations with China, the Panama Canal, the Teapot Dome scandal, and his work as Secretary of the Navy.

did.unittitle: Memorandum on the bill providing for Extradition to and from China
"Some Considerations on Chinese Exclusion" by Edwin Denby

odd.p: (including information about the U.S. Claims Commission in China and notes on the Boxer Indemnity Fund)

odd.p: (Denby served as Counsel for the accused)

Speech at University of Michigan May 17, 1924

scopecontent.p: The Personal/Biographical files include information on Denby's time in the United States Marine Corps, about land owned by Denby in Oakland County, Michigan, biographical sketches and miscellaneous financial materials. Included in this series is a collection of jokes, poems and songs that may have been written by Denby or by friends. This series also contains funeral and memorial materials from the time of Denby's death, including condolence letters sent to Mrs. Denby (which are organized alphabetically by the last name of the sender) as well as materials from Denby's actual funeral.

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series contains a variety of images of Denby, from his time at the University of Michigan, in the Navy in the Spanish American War, and his later career as a politician and cabinet member. Also included are images of China and Panama, images of United States Navy ships and planes, and unidentified portraits.
